'''Deborah Jeane Palfrey''' (March 18, 1956 – May 1, 2008),<ref name="AP050308" /> dubbed the '''D.C. Madam''' by the [[news media]], operated '''Pamela Martin and Associates''', an [[escort agency]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] Although she maintained that the company's services were legal, she was convicted on April 15, 2008 of [[Racket (crime)|racketeering]], using the mail for illegal purposes,<ref name="AP050308" /><ref name="ABC041508" /> and [[money laundering]].<ref name="ABC041508">{{Cite web|date=April 15, 2008|last=Rood|first=Justin|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Blotter/story?id=4658013&page=1|title=D.C. Madam: Guilty|publisher=[[ABC News]]|access-date=May 2, 2008 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303213225/http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/story?id=4658013&page=1 | archivedate=2016-03-03 | url-status=}}</ref> Slightly over two weeks later, facing a prison sentence of five or six years, she was found [[hanging|hanged]]. [[Autopsy]] results and the final police investigative report concluded that her death was a suicide.<ref name="AP050308">{{Cite web|last=Stacy|first=Mitch|date=May 3, 2008|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/ESCORT_LIST?SITE=NCGRE&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2008-05-03-03-52-27|title=`D.C. madam' who vowed not to go to prison kills herself|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|access-date=May 4, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505234601/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/ESCORT_LIST?SITE=NCGRE&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2008-05-03-03-52-27 <!-- Bot retrieved archive -->|archivedate=May 5, 2008}}</ref><ref name="FMT103108" /><ref name="CNN050508">{{Cite news|date=May 5, 2008|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/05/05/dc.madam/|title=D.C. Madam: 'There was no way out'|publisher=[[CNN]]|access-date=May 5, 2008 | archivedate=2016-03-04 | url-status= | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304050309/http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/05/05/dc.madam/}}</ref><ref name="SCN103108">{{Cite web|date=October 31, 2008|last=Thompson|first=Stephen|url=http://suncoastpinellas.tbo.com/content/2008/oct/31/police-officially-conclude-dc-madam-hanged-herself/news/|title=Police Officially Conclude 'D.C. Madam' Hanged Herself|publisher=The Suncoast News |access-date=October 31, 2008 | archivedate=2011-10-03 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003064142/http://suncoastpinellas.tbo.com/content/2008/oct/31/police-officially-conclude-dc-madam-hanged-herself/news/}}</ref>
== Early life == Palfrey was born in the [[Pittsburgh]] area town of [[Charleroi, Pennsylvania]], but spent her teens in [[Orlando, Florida]]. Her father was a grocer. She graduated from [[Rollins College]] with a degree in [[criminal justice]], and completed a nine-month legal course at the [[Thomas Jefferson School of Law]].<ref name="Abhor">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/28/AR2007042801192.html?nav=rss_politics|title='I Abhor Injustice,' Alleged Madam Says|date=April 29, 2007|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=April 29, 2007|archivedate=April 9, 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fwp-dyn%2Fcontent%2Farticle%2F2007%2F04%2F28%2FAR2007042801192.html%3Fnav%3Drss_politics&date=2016-04-09|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Working as a [[paralegal]] in [[San Diego, California]], she became involved in the escort business. Dismayed at how most services were run, including widespread [[Substance abuse|drug abuse]], she started her own company, recruiting mostly women over 25.<ref name="Abhor" /> In 1990, she was arrested on charges of [[Procuring (prostitution)|pimping]], [[Procuring (prostitution)|pandering]] and [[extortion]]; after fleeing to [[Montana]] she was captured while trying to cross the [[Canada–United States border|Canada–US border]] and brought back for trial. Following her conviction in 1992 she spent 18 months in prison.<ref name="Abhor" /><ref name="arrest1990">{{Cite news|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/uniontrib/20070401/news_1n1madam.html|title=Former madam comes across as an enigma|date=April 1, 2007|publisher=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |access-date=April 1, 2007 | archivedate=2016-04-09 | url-status= | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409053616/http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/uniontrib/20070401/news_1n1madam.html}}</ref> After her release, she founded Pamela Martin and Associates.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.10zenmonkeys.com/2008/05/03/death-of-a-madam/|title=Death of a Madam|access-date=November 16, 2008 | date=2008-05-03 | author=Lou Cabron | publisher=[[10 Zen Monkeys]] | archivedate=2016-01-16 | url-status= | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116124631/http://www.10zenmonkeys.com/2008/05/03/death-of-a-madam/}}</ref>
== D.C. Madam scandal == In October 2006, [[United States Postal Inspection Service]] agents posed as a couple who were interested in buying Palfrey's home as a means of accessing her property without a [[warrant (law)|warrant]].<ref name=zenmonkeys>{{Cite web|url=http://www.10zenmonkeys.com/2007/08/27/the-dc-madam-speaks/|title=The D.C. Madam Speaks|date=August 27, 2007|access-date=May 5, 2008|author=[[Susie Bright]]|publisher=[[10 Zen Monkeys]] | archivedate=2016-03-26 | url-status= | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160326221031/http://www.10zenmonkeys.com/2007/08/27/the-dc-madam-speaks/}}</ref><ref name="Gun Oct 06">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/1009061hook1.html|title=New D.C. Sex Scandal Looming? Feds target escort service in money launder, prostitution probe|publisher=[[The Smoking Gun]]|date=October 9, 2006|access-date=April 29, 2007 | archivedate=2015-09-26 | url-status= | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926151931/http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/crime/new-dc-sex-scandal-looming}}</ref> Agents froze bank accounts worth over US$500,000, seizing papers relating to [[money laundering]] and [[prostitution]] charges.<ref name="Gun Oct 06" /><ref>{{cite news | publisher = cbsnews.com | date = July 9, 2007 | title = Senator Caught In "D.C. Madam" Scandal | author = | url = https://www.cbsnews.com/news/senator-caught-in-dc-madam-scandal/}}</ref>
In early 2007, Palfrey reacted to the suicide by [[hanging]] of Brandi Britton, one of her former escort service employees, by saying, "I guess I'm made of something that Brandi Britton wasn't made of."<ref name="TIME050108" />
Palfrey's escorts charged as much as $300 per hour, and many have had professional careers. Palfrey continued to reside in [[California]], and cleared some US$2 million over 13 years in operation.<ref name="Abhor" /> Palfrey appeared on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[20/20 (American TV program)|20/20]]'' as part of an investigative report on May 4, 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/theblotter/2007/04/dc_madam_speaks.html|title="D.C. Madam" Speaks with ABC News|date=April 29, 2007|publisher=[[ABC News]]' The Blotter | archivedate=2016-03-03 | url-status= | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303173619/http://blogs.abcnews.com/theblotter/2007/04/dc_madam_speaks.html}}</ref>
In combination with Palfrey's statement that she had 10,000 to 15,000 phone numbers of [[Client (prostitution)|clients]], several clients' [[lawyer]]s contacted Palfrey to see whether accommodations could be made to keep their identities private.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Montes|first1=Sue Anne Pressley|title=Escort-service scandal set to ignite D.C. explosion|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/escort-service-scandal-set-to-ignite-dc-explosion/|website=The Seattle Times|access-date=2 April 2018|date=29 April 2007}}</ref> Ultimately, [[ABC News]], after going through what was described as "46 lb" [21 kg] of phone records, decided that none of the potential clients<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.deborahjeanepalfrey.com/telephoneRecords.html |title=Deborah Jeane Palfrey - Telephone Records |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070914201151/http://www.deborahjeanepalfrey.com/telephoneRecords.html |archivedate=September 14, 2007}}</ref> was sufficiently "newsworthy" to bother mentioning.<ref name="theind">{{Cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/world/americas/article2516738.ece|title=Network refuses to name clients of 'DC madam'|access-date=July 10, 2007|first=Andrew|last=Buncombe|work=[[The Independent]]|location=London|date=May 6, 2007 | archivedate=2007-12-30 | url-status= | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230011724/http://news.independent.co.uk/world/americas/article2516738.ece}}</ref>
Senator [[David Vitter]] (R-[[Louisiana|LA]]) acknowledged on the night of July 9, 2007, that he had been a customer of her escort service.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Murray|first1=Shailagh|title=Senator's Number on 'Madam' Phone List|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/09/AR2007070902030.html|access-date=October 13, 2014|work=The Washington Post|date=July 10, 2007}}</ref>
Thirteen former escorts and three former clients testified at her trial.<ref name="NavyTimes-2008-04-10"> {{Cite news | url=http://www.navytimes.com/news/2008/04/navy_palfrey_041008/ | title=Navy officer testifies in D.C. Madam case | publisher=[[Navy Times]] | date=April 10, 2008 | author=Chris Amos | access-date=May 26, 2010 | quote=Lt. Cmdr. Rebecca Dickinson told federal prosecutors at U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C., that she had sex with nearly every client she met while working for Deborah Jeane Palfrey from October 2005 until April 2006. | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q1NCELN1?url=http://www.navytimes.com/news/2008/04/navy_palfrey_041008/ | archivedate=May 26, 2010 | df=mdy }} </ref><ref name="GoErie2008-04-13"> {{Cite news | url=http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080413/NEWS07/804130455/-1/NEWS | title=Debt forced Naval officer to become call girl | publisher=[[Go Erie]] | date=April 13, 2008 | author=Josh Mitchell | access-date=May 26, 2010 | quote=A Navy officer who testified this week that she moonlighted for an alleged prostitution ring while stationed at the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., was nearly $300,000 in debt at the time despite a Navy income of more than $93,000, court records show. | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q1Lk6mJk?url=http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20080413%2FNEWS07%2F804130455%2F-1%2FNEWS | archivedate=May 26, 2010 | df=mdy }} </ref><ref name="WashingtonPost-2008-04"> {{Cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/04/10/AR2008041002274.html | title=Navy Officer Took Call Girl Job: Supply Official Testifies She Moonlighted at Escort Service | work=The Washington Post | date=April 10, 2010 | author=Paul Duggan | access-date=May 26, 2010 | quote=The women were compelled to testify by prosecutors under grants of immunity that prevented them from remaining silent under the Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q1NcwjGs?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/04/10/AR2008041002274.html | archivedate=May 26, 2010 | df=mdy }} </ref>
However, ''ABC News'' only published two of the names they had identified, men who were already known to have been clients of Palfrey — [[Randall L. Tobias]], a State Department official, and [[Harlan K. Ullman]], a Defense Department official.<ref name="Nytimes2007-05-05" /><ref name="AbcNews2007-04-27" /><ref name="Cnn2007-04-28" /><ref name="Wapo2007-04-28" /><ref name="State2007-04-28" /> Journalist [[Neil Lewis (journalist)|Neil A. Lewis]] reported, in ''The New York Times'', that ''[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'' would not publicize any new names.<ref name="Nytimes2007-05-05" />
The witnesses were compelled to testify, after being granted immunity from prosecution. In May 2007 a team at ''[[ABC News]]'' reported on their efforts to determine the identities of Palfrey's clients, from her phone records.<ref name="Abc2007-05-04" /> They reported how many of Palfrey's clients phoned from hotel rooms, to obfuscate their identities. They found some clients had exaggerated their importance—one who had bragged about his role in evacuating colleagues from the [[White House]] on 9/11 turned out to merely work near The White House.
On April 15, 2008, a jury found Palfrey guilty of [[money laundering]], using the mail for illegal purposes and racketeering.<ref name="AP050308" /><ref name="ABC041508" /> Palfrey believed that contrary to the U.S. Attorney's Office lower estimate, she might spend six or seven years behind bars.<ref name="OS050208" /> She faced a maximum of 55 years in prison.<ref name="WTOP050208">{{Cite web|date=May 2, 2008|url=http://www.wtop.com/?sid=1396668&nid=25|title=911 tapes released in D.C. Madam's death|publisher=[[WTOP-FM]]|access-date=May 4, 2008}}</ref>
== Death == On May 1, 2008, Palfrey was found hanging in a storage shed outside her mother's [[mobile home]] in [[Tarpon Springs, Florida]]. Police found handwritten suicide notes in the bedroom where she was staying, dated a week before her death. The autopsy and the final police investigation concluded her death was a suicide.<ref name="FMT103108">{{Cite web|date=October 31, 2008|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,445538,00.html|title=Police Close 'D.C. Madam' Investigation, Confirm She Died by Suicide|work=Fox News|agency=[[Associated Press]]|access-date=October 31, 2008 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305123313/http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/10/31/police-close-dc-madam-investigation-confirm-died-by-suicide.html | archivedate=2016-03-05 | url-status=}}</ref><ref name="SCN103108" /><ref name="JG050608">{{Cite web|date=May 6, 2008 |url=http://www.journalgazette.net/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080506/NEWS/805060344/-1/NEWS03 |title=D.C. madam calls trial 'lynching' in death note |work=[[The Journal Gazette]] |access-date=May 19, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002030200/http://www.journalgazette.net/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20080506%2FNEWS%2F805060344%2F-1%2FNEWS03 |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |df=mdy}}</ref>
Palfrey's death resulted in her conviction being [[Vacated judgment|vacated]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 21, 2008 |last=Meek |first=James Gordon |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dc/2008/05/dc-madams-conviction-dead-on-a.html |title=D.C. Madam's Conviction Dead on Arrival |work=[[New York Daily News|Daily News]] |quote=IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that...the jury verdicts are vacated and the indictment in this matter is dismissed. |access-date=May 21, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528041018/http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dc/2008/05/dc-madams-conviction-dead-on-a.html |archivedate=May 28, 2008 |df=mdy}}</ref>
=== Suicide notes === Palfrey's two handwritten notes were released to the public. In one of them, she wrote to her sister, "You must comprehend there was no way out, I.E. 'exit strategy,' for me other than the one I have chosen here." In another, she described her predicament as a "modern-day [[lynching]]". She said she feared that, at the end of serving her sentence, she would be "in my late 50s a broken, penniless and very much alone woman".<ref name="JG050608" /><ref>{{Cite news|publisher=[[CNN]] |url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/05/05/dc.madam/#cnnSTCOther1 |date=May 5, 2008 |access-date=May 5, 2008 |title=D.C. Madam: 'There was no way out' (text of suicide notes) |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304050309/http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/05/05/dc.madam/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref>
=== Speculation surrounding her death === ''[[The New York Times]]''{{'}} Patrick J. Lyons wrote on the ''Times''<nowiki>'</nowiki> blog, ''The Lede'', that some on the Internet were skeptical that her death was a suicide.<ref>{{Cite news|date=May 2, 2008 |last=Lyons |first=Patrick J. |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/02/skepticism-and-sadness-after-death-of-dc-madam/#more-1442 |title=Skepticism and Sadness After Death of 'D.C. Madam' |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=May 2, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505000951/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/02/skepticism-and-sadness-after-death-of-dc-madam/ |archivedate=May 5, 2008 }}</ref> After investigating the crime scene, however, police found "no new evidence [that] would indicate anything other than suicide by hanging," and a police investigative report released six months later concluded that her death had been a suicide.<ref name="FMT103108" /><ref name="SCN103108" /> The police stated that Palfrey's family believed the notes were written by Palfrey.<ref>{{Cite news|date=May 5, 2008|url=http://www.wifr.com/home/headlines/18580059.html|title=In suicide note, 'D.C. Madam' said she didn't want prison|author=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=WIFR 23|access-date=August 30, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|date=May 5, 2008|last=Dvorak|first=Petula|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2008/05/05/ST2008050501054.html|title=Palfrey Suicide Notes Are Released|work=The Washington Post|access-date=May 5, 2008}}</ref>
In early 2007, Palfrey learned of the death, apparently through suicide by [[hanging]], of [[Brandi Britton]], one of her former escort service employees.<ref name="TIME050108" /> Palfrey reacted to this news by saying, "I guess I'm made of something that Brandy Britton wasn't made of." According to her former attorney, [[Montgomery Blair Sibley]], she even took the extraordinary step of writing directly to the prosecutor, promising to show more resolve than Britton.<ref name=WhyJustHer />
Journalist [[Dan Moldea]], who was working with Palfrey on a book, recalled that in a 2007 conversation, Palfrey told him, "I am not going back to prison. I will commit suicide first."<ref name="OS050208">{{Cite web|date=May 2, 2008|last=Mairano|first=Willoughby|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-madam0208may02,0,4270322.story|title=D.C. madam's mystery death: The Orlando connection|publisher=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|access-date=May 2, 2008}}</ref> He said her previous prison experience had [[psychological trauma|traumatized]] her and she felt she couldn't do it again.<ref name="AP050308" /><ref name="TIME050108">{{Cite news|date=May 1, 2008 |last=Zagorin |first=Adam |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1736687,00.html |title=D.C. Madam: Suicide Before Prison |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=May 1, 2008 |archivedate=March 8, 2016 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308060216/http://content.time.com/time/nation/article/0%2C8599%2C1736687%2C00.html }}</ref>
== Palfrey's customer list == On July 9, 2007, Palfrey released the supposed entirety of her phone records for public viewing and downloading on the Internet in [[TIFF]] format, though days prior to this, her civil attorney Montgomery Blair Sibley had dispatched 54 [[CD-ROM]] copies to researchers, activists, and journalists.
=== 2016 Presidential Election === [[Montgomery Blair Sibley|Sibley]], Palfrey's former attorney, claims to have her phone records and that they are relevant to the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wtop.com/presidential-election/2016/03/ex-lawyer-asks-supreme-court-to-allow-release-of-d-c-madam-phone-records-or-else/|title=Ex-lawyer asks Supreme Court to allow release of 'D.C. Madam' phone records - or else|website=WTOP|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2016-03-31/dc-madams-attorney-says-election-bombshell-already-online|title=D.C. Madam's Attorney Says Election Bombshell Already Online|last=Nelson|first=Steven|date=2016-03-31|website=US News & World Report|access-date=2016-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.insideedition.com/headlines/15618-dc-madams-attorney-i-have-bombshell-information-that-could-affect-2016-election|title=D.C. Madam's Attorney: I Have Bombshell Information That Could Affect 2016 Election|website=Inside Edition|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.therightperspective.org/2016/04/01/has-anonymous-dropped-ted-cruz-dc-madam-phone-dox/|title=Has Anonymous Dropped Ted Cruz 'DC Madam' Phone Dox?|website=The Right Perspective|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/reliable-source/wp/2016/02/02/former-lawyer-for-the-d-c-madam-says-names-in-her-records-could-be-relevant-to-election/|title=Former lawyer for the 'D.C. Madam' says names in her records could be 'relevant' to election|last=Heil|first=Emily|date=2016-02-02|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> In April 2016, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the request to lift a lower court order, in place since 2007, that bars Sibley from releasing any information about her records.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/scotus-denies-request-dc-madam-s-attorney-release-info-n551121?cid=sm_twitter_feed_politics|title=SCOTUS Denies Request from D.C. Madam's Attorney to Release Info|website=NBC News|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref>
